channel.title: Interleaved RSS Feed
channel.description: This is an interleaved feed of the most recent entries from each RSS source, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Jet Engines Are Breaking Down. Their Manufacturers Are Raking In Cash.
item.description: Many in the aviation industry are railing against misaligned incentives in the engine-making business, which makes profit through repair-shop visits and spare parts.

item.title: Heineken shares fall 8% after first-half profit miss
item.description: Operting profit showed organic growth of 12.5%, below a company-compiled consensus forecast of 13.2%.

item.title: Big Pharma Rallies and Moves Past Obesity
item.description: The rotation into laggard pharmaceutical stocks is being helped by optimism over regulations.

item.title: McDonald's earnings, revenue miss estimates as consumer pullback worsens
item.description: McDonald's stock has fallen 15% year to date, dragging its market value down to $181.2 billion.

item.title: In a Troubled Box Office, Premium Still Sells
item.description: “Deadpool & Wolverine” is bringing crowds back to theaters. For IMAX, they never left.

item.title: Philips shares jump 10.5% as second-quarter sales grow despite China weakness
item.description: Shares of Philips jumped in early deals Monday after the Dutch device maker reported better-than-expected second-quarter earnings.

item.title: Investors Embrace Bond Funds Before Rates Start to Fall
item.description: Fixed-income exchange-traded funds collected more money than ever during the year’s first half.

item.title: The 'great rotation' faces its biggest test yet: earnings from Microsoft, Meta, Apple and Amazon
item.description: In his weekly column, Jim Cramer writes that the 'great rotation' faces its biggest test yet with earnings from Microsoft, Meta, Apple and Amazon.

item.title: Luxury Brands Are in a Winner-Takes-All Phase
item.description: Hermès captured the lion’s share of growth in luxury-goods spending in the second quarter, while everyone else lagged behind.

item.title: Dexcom shares plunge more than 40% for worst day on record
item.description: Dexcom, which had its stock market debut in 2005, had its worst day ever after lowering its full-year guidance.
